<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 139, 566, 158]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 171, 245, 190]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 201, 390, 220]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 220, 586, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 276, 233, 294]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 297, 757, 336]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 350, 504, 388]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 415, 391, 434]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 440, 539, 470]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 492, 339, 511]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 515, 435, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 616, 599, 635]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 649, 161, 667]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 677, 589, 730]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 772, 247, 790]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 797, 599, 833]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 833, 599, 853]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 860, 561, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(k\) such that the line \(y = 9kx + 1\) does not meet the curve \(y = kx^{2} + 3x(2k + 1) + 4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 586, 91]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \((3 - 5\sqrt{3})x^{2} + (2\sqrt{3} +5)x - 1 = 0\), giving your solutions in the form \(a + b\sqrt{3}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are rational numbers. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(y = a\sin bx + c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants, passes through the points \((4\pi , 11)\) and \(\left(- \frac{4\pi}{3}, 5\right)\). It is given that \(a\sin bx + c\) has period \(16\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 143, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 125, 430, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the exact values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 419, 146, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 418, 861, 438]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to part (a), find the coordinates of the minimum point on the curve for

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 433, 217, 452]]<|/det|>
\(0\leqslant x\leqslant 16\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 636, 106]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{1}{2x - 1} +\frac{4}{(2x - 1)^2}\) can be written as \(\frac{2x + 3}{(2x - 1)^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 265, 146, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 259, 923, 293]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int_{2}^{5} \frac{2x + 3}{(2x - 1)^2} \mathrm{d}x\), giving your answer in the form \(a + \ln b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 504, 104]]<|/det|>
Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that \(y = \frac{\ln(2x^2 - 3)}{3x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 112, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 109, 230, 133]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 146, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 408, 868, 428]]<|/det|>
Hence find the approximate change in \(y\) when \(x\) increases from 2 to \(2 + h\), where \(h\) is small. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 597, 144, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
At the instant when \(x = 2, y\) is increasing at the rate of 4 units per second. Find the corresponding rate of increase in \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 77, 94, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve \(y = 1 + \tan 3x\) at the point \(P\) with \(x\)-coordinate \(\frac{\pi}{12}\), meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 767, 145]]<|/det|>
The line \(x = \frac{\pi}{12}\) meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(R\). Find the area of the triangle \(PQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A curve \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} = (2 - 3x)^{-\frac{1}{3}}\). The curve passes through the point \((- 2, 10.2)\). The gradient of the tangent to the curve at \((- 2, 10.2)\) is \(-6\). Find \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 660, 92]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in metres and all times are in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 92, 636, 128]]<|/det|>
A particle \(A\) is moving in the direction \(\binom{- 20}{21}\) with a speed of 58.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 386, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity vector of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 279, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
Given that \(A\) is initially at the point with position vector \(\binom{- 5}{- 3}\), write down the position vector of \(A\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 465, 730, 501]]<|/det|>
A particle \(B\) starts to move such that its position vector at time \(t\) is \(\binom{- 35t + 4}{44t - 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 144, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 490, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the displacement vector \(\overrightarrow{AB}\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 77, 146, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 895, 98]]<|/det|>
Hence find the distance \(AB\), at time \(t\), in the form \(\sqrt{pt^2 + qt + r}\), where \(p, q\) and \(r\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 144, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) when the distance \(AB\) is \(\sqrt{6}\), giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 521, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 855, 92]]<|/det|>
The function f is such that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \ln (5x + 2)\), for \(x > a\), where \(a\) is as small as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 181, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 405, 122]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 165, 180, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 398, 184]]<|/det|>
Hence find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 227, 180, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 442, 246]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\), stating its domain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 460, 180, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\), stating the exact values of the intercepts of the curves with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 504, 850, 794]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 831, 100]]<|/det|>
The function g is such that \(\mathrm{~g~:~}x\mapsto x^{\frac{1}{2}} - 4\), for \(x > 0\). Solve the equation \(\mathrm{g}^{2}(x) = -2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 77, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of an arithmetic progression are \(\sin 3x\), \(5\sin 3x\), \(9\sin 3x\). Find the exact values of \(x\), where \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}\), for which the sum to twenty terms is equal to 390. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 777, 94]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of a geometric progression are \(20\cos y\), \(10\cos^2 y\), \(5\cos^3 y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 106, 180, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 106, 591, 125]]<|/det|>
Explain why this progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 308, 180, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 308, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(y\), where \(y\) is in radians and \(0 < y < 2\), for which the sum to infinity is 9. Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 73, 562, 88]]<|/det|>
